Sure you can quote me all you want.  When one has been in the paranormal 
(=
and Scientific) field as long as I have, one soon learns the difference 
be=
tween "real" and "healthy Skepticism" and  people who put on a fake 
"skept=
ical" persona in an effort to assuage their emotional issues and 
fears.
  =
 Not all Scientists who Call themselves "scientists" are scientists. Ya 
go=
tta admit , the subject of ghosts, spirts, etc. is pretty darn scary, if 
y=
our only contact with it is what you learn from kids stories and 1950's 
ho=
rror movies.  Who wants to live in a world with stuff like that lurking 
ar=
ound in dark rooms and closets?.  Most people as children learn to sleep 
w=
ith the lights off by desperately wishing "there are no ghosts" until 
they=
 finally" believe" it.

  Is it any wonder why MANY people (including the s=
upposedly educated) 
react emotionally and fearful when someone brings up p=
aranormal subject 
matter in a serious context?  Denial is the only defense=
 that they had 
developed as a child.  To even study the truth and read an =
authoritative 
book on the subject is a scary prospect for such people, so =
they usually 
stay in a relatively ignorant state in these matters, and nev=
er grow away 
from the need of such an emotional defense. 

 Only an intell=
ectually honest person who can separate himself from his 
emotions and has =
a thirst and drive for finding out the truth about what 
man does not yet k=
now about can make a good Scientist. Education (on the 
current  state of a=
ffairs) is not enough.  A real and constructive 
Skepticism is also part of=
 being a Scientist as is the ability to change 
one's opinion should the ev=
idence warrant it.  A  Pseudo-Skeptic can't do 
that no matter how overwhel=
ming the evidence may be--if they are exposed 
to any evidence at all.  The=
y know if to accept the things that frighten 
them as being "legit" they co=
uld find themselves up all night with the 
lights on sucking their thumbs.
=

I like the quote (it think its by Coleridge)  "that it is impossible to 
r=
eason a man out of a position he was never reasoned into in the first 
plac=
e"

TOM

Wow, Tom...excellent way to sort=
 and define the differences. Do you mind 
if I quote you on that? Would lik=
e to share that thought with some friends 
I was just discussing that point=
 with...

M

(have not formally introduced myself, but very much enjoying t=
he work and 
discussions here. Thanks to you all.)

Michelle D. Ayers; Sent=
 from iPhone

On Mar 4, 2010, at 8:14 AM, Tom_Ray@... wrote:

 =


What Frank is referring to is more properly termed a "Pseudo-Skeptic". 
I=
ndeed Skepticism is a vital part of scientific investigations, but it's 
Sk=
epticism based on consideration of the facts and  expressing a caution 
or =
difference of opinion is what is useful in the Scientific community.  A 
ps=
eudo Skeptic is characterized by a person who clearly does not know the 
su=
bject area other than through what may be termed "common knowledge" or, 
at=
 best, a brief overview of the literature.  A  Pseudo skeptic's 
"opinions"=
 are based primarily on an emotional attitude towards the 
subject matter r=
ather than what few "facts" he knows.  Its a psychological 
defense he uses=
 to shore up his status, the validity of his work, and to 
cope with things=
 that frighten him. 

A real Skeptic is a friend with a difference of opini=
on based on a genuine 
desire to help and sufficient data on the subject at=
 hand to know what 
he/she is talking about.  We, as Scientists must always=
 have a health dose 
of real Skepticism.  Otherwise we risk being the exact=
 inverse of the 
Pseudo skeptic---the "FLAKE".  The Flake is the type who w=
ill believe 
anything.  Just as the Pseudo Skeptic has a need to reject thi=
ngs on 
emotional grounds, the Flake has a need to accept EVERYTHING on emo=
tional 
grounds.  Any shadow,  sound, or corner of the eye flash just HAS t=
o be a 
ghost or spirit. ----or whatever.  I think you know the type, and  =
 these 
"flakes" are what Pseudo skeptics accuse us who are serious about 
=
paranormal studies  of being.  Perhaps its one of the reasons they get us 
=
so angry. 







Rj <rasterer@...>

I've heard the same said for the evp researchers!  But it's no=
t that 
simple in either case:
the last block that you reference has small =
print that says "Compare the 
hypothesis to the experiment's conclusion".  =
Which of course you can't do 
unless you already visited the hypothesis blo=
ck and have a hypothesis to 
which to compare.  That in turn has small prin=
t which says "predict the 
outcome of the problem", which of course you can=
't do either unless you've 
already visited the earlier block of Purpose ("=
state the problem").

I don't think it's helpful to deny good evidence, whe=
ther it is good 
evidence from someone claiming to have detected spirits, o=
r whether it is 
good evidence from someone claiming that people can mistak=
e noise for 
speech or random radio tunings for spirit control.  That's why=
 the 
scientific method is valuable: it keeps both the skeptic and the beli=
ever 
real.

<td bgcolor=3Dwhite><font size=3D3>I've heard the same said for the evp re=
searchers!
 But it's not that simple in either case:<br>
the last bloc=
k that you reference has small print that says "Compare
the hypothesis=
 to the experiment's conclusion".  Which of course
you can't do u=
nless you already visited the hypothesis block and have a
hypothesis to whi=
ch to compare.  That in turn has small print which
says "predict =
the outcome of the problem", which of course you
can't do either unles=
s you've already visited the earlier block of Purpose
("state the prob=
lem").<br>
<br>
I don't think it's helpful to deny good evidence, whet=
her it is good evidence
from someone claiming to have detected spirits, or =
whether it is good evidence
from someone claiming that people can mistake n=
oise for speech or random
radio tunings for spirit control.  That's wh=
y the scientific method
is valuable: it keeps both the skeptic and the beli=
ever real.<br>
